item.title: UK sends Royal Navy ships to patrol Jersey amid fishing row with France
item.description: The PM says he supports Jersey as French fishing boats protest against new post-Brexit rules.

item.title: Millions to vote in bumper set of elections
item.description: Local and national contests - many delayed by Covid - are taking place in England, Scotland and Wales.

item.title: Antony Blinken: US will respond to reckless Russian acts
item.description: The US would prefer more stable and predictable ties with Russia, Antony Blinken tells the BBC.

item.title: No full-time return to the office for over a million
item.description: Almost all of 50 big UK firms tell the BBC staff will divide their time between home and office in future.

item.title: Covid-19: Polls open for elections and US backs waiver on vaccine patents
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Thursday morning.

item.title: Elections 2021: What can't I do in a polling station?
item.description: The rules on everything from whether you can take a selfie to voting while drunk.

item.title: Covid: US backs waiver on vaccine patents to boost supply
item.description: Supporters say the move would increase vaccine production but the pharmaceutical industry disagrees.

item.title: India Covid: Government says new variant linked to surge
item.description: The deadly second wave of the virus has already overwhelmed India's healthcare system.

item.title: Father calls for pornography sites to require proof of age
item.description: A father and an Oxford student seek a High Court hearing to require age verification on porn sites.

item.title: Millions at security risk from old routers, Which? warns
item.description: Research by Which? looked at a selection of older routers still being used by customers.

item.title: Chelsea 2-0 Real Madrid (agg 3-1): Thomas Tuchel's side set up all-English Champions League final
item.description: Chelsea defeat Real Madrid to set up an all-English Champions League final against Manchester City on 29 May in Istanbul.

item.title: The Papers: PM 'sends gunboats to Jersey' and 'Navy to face the French'
item.description: The UK sending Royal Navy vessels to Jersey amid a row over fishing rights with France features on the front pages.

item.title: Mental health: 'We need to care for patients, but also ourselves'
item.description: Following the death of his cousin, Dr Dan Gearon created the charity, You Okay, Doc?

item.title: Drone trucker: Sharing wild Australian landscapes for a cause
item.description: Truck driver Ben Stamatovich uses a drone to capture rugged landscapes on his journeys across Australia.

item.title: Back to work: 'We're not going back to the office'
item.description: Tara Tomes of East Village PR firm in Birmingham explains why she's ditching the office.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: The mental strain of the delayed Olympics
item.description: Two Olympic hopefuls tell the BBC about the mental health impact of the delay to the Tokyo games.

item.title: Prince blamed for shooting one of Europe's biggest bears
item.description: Environmental groups suspect a prince from Austria killed the brown bear while hunting in Romania.

item.title: Covid: Black leaders blame lower vaccine take-up on racism
item.description: Mistrust and inequality may explain why vaccine take-up is lower in the black community, say campaigners.

item.title: Safe Sweden faces up to wave of women's killings
item.description: A spate of deaths reignites a debate about domestic violence in a country praised for gender equality.

item.title: Lelush: How a sulky Russian model became China's slacker icon
item.description: Getting trapped in a boy band reality TV contest was just the start of Lelush's unlikely journey.

item.title: While She Sleeps: Why I spend big subscribing to my favourite band
item.description: Sheffield band While She Sleeps say they've created 'a sustainable model' for the music industry.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: Families stranded in Pakistan, India and Bangladesh
item.description: The cost of hotel quarantine in the UK is too high for some families, who have had to delay their return instead.

item.title: Zulu Queen: Hundreds of mourners hold parade ahead of funeral
item.description: South Africa's Zulu nation awaits a decision on who will succeed the queen, who died last month.

item.title: 'We are desperate to go travelling again'
item.description: "Digital nomads" aim to get back to mobile working after Covid, with many countries wooing them.

item.title: Night Fever: How club culture has moved with the times
item.description: A new show looks at the origins of disco culture in the 1960s and how it's developed since.

item.title: Coronavirus: How India descended into Covid-19 chaos
item.description: Experts tell the BBC that delays in decision-making worsened the crisis of India's second wave.

item.title: Covid and cancer: The young scientists working overtime to combat lockdown disruption
item.description: Lab staff are working long unpaid hours to reduce the impact Covid is having on cancer research.

item.title: 'I've always thought I was British'
item.description: BBC Panorama speaks to young people who say their dreams have been crushed due to their immigration status.

item.title: The company where colleagues decide your salary
item.description: A software firm in Argentina is trying a radical experiment in employee transparency and democracy.

item.title: Napoleon's incendiary legacy divides France 200 years on
item.description: Dictatorship and slavery taint the Napoleonic reforms that shaped modern France.

item.title: Covid cases at Everest base camp raise fears of serious outbreak
item.description: Climbers say a growing number of people have tested positive, despite government denials.

item.title: Cardiff University team wants to change 'lad culture' perceptions
item.description: The students stepped forward to help chaperone women home after a hoax rape post on social media.

item.title: Covid-19: Care home residents can go on outdoor trips without isolating
item.description: People in residential care in England are now allowed low-risk trips outside without isolating afterwards.

item.title: Kai Havertz: 'Chelsea forward ignites as Blues' season reaches peak of possibilities'
item.description: Kai Havertz's disjointed and illness-affected start to the season looked a distant memory as the German found his feet in time for a Champions League final, writes Phil McNulty.

item.title: British and Irish Lions: Wales great Alun Wyn Jones to captain squad
item.description: Wales great Alun Wyn Jones is to be confirmed as captain of the British and Irish Lions for the tour of South Africa.

item.title: 'It's more personal' - Alvarez sends Saunders message in Texas
item.description: Saul 'Canelo' Alvarez says Billy Joe Saunders' pursuit of him has made Saturday's Texas fight "more personal".

item.title: 'A lot of my anger was pain and unhappiness - we have to break the cycle of abuse'
item.description: In a new documentary, former England, Arsenal, Crystal Palace and West Ham striker Ian Wright shares his own story of growing up in a psychologically abusive and violent home.

item.title: Man City could move for Rice - Thursday's gossip
item.description: Manchester City could make Declan Rice move if Fernandinho leaves, Ibrahima Konate is set to join Liverpool on a five-year deal, Tottenham are in talks with Inter boss Antonio Conte, plus more.

item.title: Election 2021: How do I vote and why could results take longer?
item.description: About 48 million people will be able to vote in a series of elections on Thursday 6 May.

item.title: Elections 2021: How to follow the results on the BBC
item.description: Find out how to keep up to date with live election results on TV, radio, online and on social media.

item.title: 2021 elections: What elections can I vote in this year?
item.description: National elections in Scotland and Wales and local elections in England are scheduled for 6 May 2021.

item.title: Welsh election 2021: Who should I vote for? Compare party policies
item.description: Compare where the parties stand on key issues - from Covid-19 and the NHS to education and the environment.

item.title: Elections 2021: How the BBC reports polling day
item.description: The BBC is not allowed to report details of campaigning while the polls are open.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: When can I holiday abroad, and which countries will be on the green list?
item.description: A new "traffic light" system for travel will classify countries as green, amber or red.

item.title: Covid: What are my money-back rights for holidays abroad?
item.description: Quarantine-free overseas holidays may soon be possible, but what are my refund and travel insurance rights?

item.title: Covid: What are the social distancing rules and the rule of six?
item.description: Rules on hugging and social distancing in England are being reviewed.

item.title: What are the India, Brazil, South Africa and UK variants?
item.description: The world is carefully monitoring Covid for mutations that help it spread better or resist vaccines.

item.title: How many cases in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Northern Ireland is the latest part of the UK to lift some of the restrictions designed to stop the spread of Covid-19.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People 40 or over in England are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the rollout continues.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk on transport?
item.description: As UK coronavirus restrictions continue to be relaxed, public transport could become much busier.

item.title: Covid: Restaurants and pubs are reopening, but what are the rules?
item.description: Northern Ireland follows England, Scotland and Wales in allowing venues to reopen outdoors.

item.title: When does the stamp duty holiday in England and Northern Ireland end?
item.description: What is the stamp duty holiday and when will it finish?

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go.... and who with?
item.description: The rules on having a holiday in the UK have been relaxed - but restrictions remain.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.
